entry.title: Combined summary - 2 step confirmation system
entry.summary: The email thread discusses two major concerns regarding Bitcoin. The first concern is the fear of losing bitcoin due to a mistake while entering the address. Bitcoin addresses have a "checksum", making it almost impossible to input the wrong address. However, there is a risk of malware that can replace the intended address with one controlled by the malware author. This makes verifying the correct address still a concern. To address this issue, the beneficiary's wallet can generate a signed payment request instead of just an address. Another way to address this issue is to send the transaction to the beneficiary in a private channel instead of broadcasting it. The beneficiary will not broadcast the transaction if he would not receive money as a result of it or if he sees the transaction was not constructed correctly to his wish. The second concern is about having the option to use some sort of 2-step confirmation system when dealing with people they do not know. In such cases, the escrow system can be used with or without an arbitrator. Without an arbitrator, the case usually depends on time or revealing x to a known hash. With an arbitrator, the system can be elaborately built in a sheltered model where a compromised arbitrator can only revert transactions but not steal. Google "bitcoin multisig" and "bitcoin escrow" to find support in the core bitcoin protocol for deals. Ryan has done large deals with the use of "2 of 3 multisig", but it is a big pain with poor tooling and expensive transactions. Unless you are dealing with over 100 bitcoin, it is easier to use a trusted (single party) escrow. The proposed system would act as an escrow, where if the two people involved in the transaction approve within X hours, the coin returns to the original person. When discussing Bitcoin with non-Bitcoin users, two of their major concerns are highlighted. Firstly, the fear that if they enter an incorrect address, they will not be able to retrieve their Bitcoin. Secondly, they would like the option of a two-step confirmation system when dealing with people they do not know. This would allow them to give final approval of the transaction and act as an escrow if both parties approve within a certain timeframe. The two-step system would work for either concern and could potentially alleviate anxiety around Bitcoin transactions. The author acknowledges that this may not be the correct forum for such thoughts but thanks the reader for their time. All of the methods mentioned in the email do not require any change to the Bitcoin network or blockchain. A wallet developer can implement all these approaches without negotiating with Bitcoin developers.
